Issues.Title: Cleanup for utilization of target new
Issues.Body:
Tweaks the editor config settings to encourage behavior that matches our coding style:

- We prefer `Foo foo = new()` over `var foo =`.
- `var` for built in types is an error
- Expression bodied members are always ok

A number of the rules got added by just using the editor. I'll continue to iterate.

Changed a big chunk of the code to use target typed new using fixers and regex's for the majority of the changes.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9527)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Cleanup for utilization of target new" (#9527)

Issues.Title: Request to backport fix to NET framework
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

NET 4.8

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

Hi,

I'm aware I'm wrong here for NET framework issues (as noted in https://github.com/dotnet/winforms#please-note).

However: Both  of these links do not work.

- The "developers community" link fails immediatly with a 403. And if I try to submit I get a "Unexpected error. Sorry, we couldn't send your report, because the server connection timed out.". If I try to submit it from with Visual Studio it also just hangs with "Trying to log in". Frustrating.
- The link to "Product support" website works, but it asks me for a "eligible support plan". Do I need to purchase support for this?

Background: We're running into #2979 and have no easy way to fix it (third party library: DevExpress) and would like to see it fixed.

Again, sorry for the ticket but I have no clue what else to do.

I'd appreciate any help.

Cheers from Germany


### Steps to reproduce

Try to report the issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Request to backport fix to NET framework" (#9515)

Issues.Title: `PropertyStore` refactor for generic wrappers
Issues.Body:
This PR refactors the `PropertyStore` wrappers to generics so they can be used on other struct types. It also adds separate functions for structs with `SetValue<T>`, `GetValue<T>`, and `TryGetValue<T>`.



Fixes #8990

Issues.Title: Nullability annotations in ComponentDesigner and child classes
Issues.Body:
### Background and motivation

As discussed [here](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/9408#discussion_r1249753476), `ComponentDesigner` has a public `Component` property that is not set in the constructor, but in the `Initialize` method. This property implicitly implements the `IDesigner` interface, that expects it not to be null. Many parts of the code both in `ComponentDesigner` and its child classes also don't guard its value against null.
Also, all internal construction of this class call the `Initialize` method right after creation.

### API Proposal

Given the above, I guess the least bad choice would be to force `Component` to be not null.

### API Usage

NA

### Alternative Designs

An alternative would be to make this property nullable, with an explicit implementation of the `IDesigner` interface, and add many `!` (or null checks) all over the codebase.
Another one would be not to annotate this property and leave it undefinitely in an undefined state.

### Risks

The main risk here is to manipulate an uninitialized `ComponentDesigner` (which I think already comes with risks) without alerting users that `Component` can actually be null in such a case.

### Will this feature affect UI controls?

Not directly
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Nullability annotations in ComponentDesigner and child classes" (#9502)

Issues.Title: Enable nullability in CodeDomSerializer
Issues.Body:
Follow up to #9099

## Proposed changes

- Enable nullability in CodeDomSerializer
- Enable nullability in ResourceCodeDomSerializer (continued from #9457)
